name: Wolf
prompt: meru archetypal symbol of a wolf, bold angular silhouette of a wolf's head in profile, prominent pointed ears, elongated snout, open howling mouth, upward energy, primal wildness, pure black ink on white background, high contrast monochrome, no colors, no grays, recognizable yet abstract symbolic form, clear archetypal meaning, bold black strokes, sharp defined edges, strong silhouette, maximum contrast, iconic symbolic representation, perfect for SVG conversion, universally recognizable wolf archetype
interpretation:
Dreaming of a wolf might invite you to reconnect with instinct, courage, or the wilder edges of your nature. Jung and Hillman might suggest the wolf points toward autonomous, untamed energies within—the parts of yourself that know how to survive and protect. Mythologically, as Campbell and Estés show, the wolf often appears as a companion in the dark woods of the soul, a guide to intuition and hidden knowing. In some traditions, the wolf may act as an initiator or psychopomp, ushering you into a new level of awareness or testing your authenticity. Esoteric sources might associate the wolf with the threshold between worlds, a being at home in both light and shadow. In nondual teachings, the wolf’s howl could be a call to recognize your own fierce presence as both form and emptiness. If the wolf visits your dream, you might ask what is calling for courage or protection in your life—and consider how you relate to both solitude and belonging.

— Inspired by Jung, Hillman, Estés, Grof, Campbell, Meade, Wilber, ARAS, and others.
sources: C.G. Jung, Man and His Symbols
Clarissa Pinkola Estés, Women Who Run With the Wolves
Archive for Research in Archetypal Symbolism (ARAS)
Chevalier & Gheerbrant, Dictionary of Symbols
Joseph Campbell, The Power of Myth

name: Lion
prompt: meru archetypal symbol of a lion, bold frontal or profile silhouette with a flowing mane radiating outward, prominent nose and eyes, sense of regality and strength, pure black ink on white background, high contrast monochrome, no colors, no grays, recognizable yet abstract symbolic form, clear archetypal meaning, bold black strokes, strong silhouette, maximum contrast, iconic symbolic representation, perfect for SVG conversion, universally recognizable lion archetype
interpretation:
Encountering a lion in a dream may suggest the stirring of dignity, creative power, or leadership. Jung might see the lion as an image of the Self, expressing both animal vitality and a unifying radiance. Hillman could point to the lion’s presence as an opportunity to embody majesty or to reflect on your place of sovereignty. In myth, lions often stand as guardians or challengers—sometimes inviting you to face the forces that test your worthiness. Esoteric and alchemical perspectives sometimes link the lion to gold, sunlight, or the transformative fire of the soul. Tantric and Dzogchen traditions may view the lion as a symbol of awareness’s natural nobility and confidence. If a lion appears to you, it may be worth asking where your strength wishes to express itself, or where you are called to stand your ground and claim your place in the sun.

— Inspired by Jung, Hillman, Campbell, Grof, Crowley, Chevalier & Gheerbrant, Kṣemarāja, Longchenpa, et al.
sources: C.G. Jung, Man and His Symbols
Chevalier & Gheerbrant, Dictionary of Symbols
Joseph Campbell, The Power of Myth
Aleister Crowley, The Book of Thoth
Longchenpa, The Practice of Dzogchen

name: Bear
prompt: meru archetypal symbol of a bear, powerful compact body, broad head with rounded ears, posture of stability and readiness, protective and nurturing energy, pure black ink on white background, high contrast monochrome, no colors, no grays, recognizable yet abstract symbolic form, clear archetypal meaning, bold black strokes, rounded strong edges, strong silhouette, maximum contrast, iconic symbolic representation, perfect for SVG conversion, universally recognizable bear archetype
interpretation:
Meeting the bear in dreams might point to a time for retreat, protection, or inner healing. Jung and Hillman might interpret the bear as an invitation to draw on your own rooted strength and to honor the wisdom found in solitude. Across cultures, the bear is sometimes seen as an ancestor, a healer, or a guardian of hidden knowledge. Myths might depict the bear as a teacher of boundaries, renewal, or the cyclical rhythms of life and rest. Esoteric writers sometimes see the bear as a symbol of deep transformation—of returning to the earth to emerge renewed. Nondual traditions may recognize in the bear a spaciousness or luminous holding, inviting you to rest in the fullness of being. If bear energy appears to you, consider where you might need to honor cycles of activity and retreat, or how you might draw upon protective or nurturing instincts.

— Inspired by Jung, Hillman, Estés, Campbell, Grof, ARAS, Mindell, and others.

name: Fox

interpretation:
The fox in dreams may signal adaptability, resourcefulness, or the spirit of the trickster. Jung and Hillman might suggest the fox represents subtle intelligence—an aspect of psyche that thrives in complexity and paradox. In myth and folklore, the fox often appears as a shapeshifter or teacher of reversals, sometimes leading you to question appearances or to laugh at your own seriousness. Esoteric traditions might frame the fox as a guide through illusions, an initiator into the mysteries of transformation. Tantric and Dzogchen perspectives may point to the playful, elusive quality of awareness mirrored in the fox’s movements. If fox energy visits you, you could reflect on where adaptation or cunning might serve you—or whether a touch of humor and shapeshifting is needed in your present situation.

— Inspired by Jung, Hillman, Campbell, Meade, ARAS, Crowley, and others.

name: Circle
prompt: meru archetypal symbol of a circle, perfect unbroken circle, unity and completion, eternal round, pure black ink on white background, high contrast monochrome, no colors, no grays, recognizable yet abstract symbolic form, clear archetypal meaning, bold black strokes, strong silhouette, maximum contrast, iconic symbolic representation, perfect for SVG conversion, universally recognizable circle archetype
interpretation:
Encountering the circle in dreams or visions may signal a call to explore unified completion and eternal wholeness. Jung might interpret the circle as a symbol of individuation and wholeness, while Hillman could see it as an invitation to engage with the sacred dimensions of psyche. Mythologically, the circle appears across cultures as a symbol of unity, completion. Esoteric traditions might frame it as a key to understanding unified completion and eternal wholeness. If the circle appears in your experience, consider what aspects of unified completion and eternal wholeness are seeking attention in your life.

— Inspired by Jung, Hillman, Campbell, Grof, ARAS, and archetypal wisdom traditions.
sources: C.G. Jung, Man and His Symbols
James Hillman, Re-Visioning Psychology
Joseph Campbell, The Hero with a Thousand Faces
